page.description: Send an email using the SparkPost service.
page.prototype: p Result = email_send_sparkpost(key as c, message as A)

argument.name: message
argument.description: Can be a JSON string that defines the message or a dot variable with message properties. See examples below.

return.name: Result
return.description: Returns a dot variable that includes information about whether or not the message was delivered to the SparkPost server. The returned dot variable does not include information as to whether or not the message was delivered to each recipient. The return value also includes the JSON message definition that was constructed from the *[xb:message]* object.

section.title: Using email_send_sparkpost

description.p: This Xbasic helper function can be used to send e-mail using the SparkPost service. You must first go to sparkpost.com to get an API key. You will also be required to verify ownership of your sending domain.
Once you have your API key and have verified your domain ownership, you can send e-mail.

section.note: Currently the *[xb:email_send_sparkpost()]* function does not expose the ability to use merge variables in the HTML message. If you need this functionality, you must compose the message JSON manually. Refer to the [SparkPost documentation].

section.example: dim ms as p ms.send_to = "john@acme.com:Optional friendly name for John Smith,sally@acme.com" ms.reply_to = "harry@acme.com" 'optional - use same format as send_to ms.send_to_cc = "bill@acme.com" ' optional - use same format as send_to ms.send_to_bcc = "marisa@acme.com" ' optional - use same format as send_to ms.from_email = "sendername@acme.com" ms.from_name = "Sales at Acme" 'friendly name - optional ms.subject = "Information You Requested" ms.message_html = "Here is the information you requested." ms.message_text = "Plain text version of the message" ms.attachments = "c:\alphasports\invoice.pdf,c:\alphasports\vendorlist.pdf" dim key as c = "your sparkpostkey" pp = email_send_SparkPost(key,ms)

description.p: The body of your HTML message can optionally include in-line images. To define in-line images you can either use a property that specifies a comma-delimited list of image filenames, or you can use an array syntax:

section.example: dim ms.inlineImagesArray[1] as p ms.inlineImagesArray[1].name = "myimage1.jpeg" ms.inlineImagesArray[1].type = resolve_mime_type("jpg") ms.inlineImagesArray[1].content = base64encode(file.to_blob("C:\Images\4296.JPG"))

description.p: Notice that the comma delimited names syntax specifies the image name (the name by which you will refer to the image in the HTML body) with a | delimiter. In the above example, the image name is 'myimage1.jpeg'

section.title: Example: Click Tracking

description.p: SparkPost allows you to specify options, such as open_tracking and click_tracking (see [SparkPost API documentation]).
In build 4612 and newer, you can pass in these options to the email_send_sparkpost() function as shown below:

section.example:
dim ms as p
'xbasic commands to set required properties of mp not shown
ms.options.open_tracking = .f. ms.options.click_tracking = .f. dim key as c = "your sparkpostkey"
dim pp as p pp = email_send_sparkpost(key,ms)
